text: hope that God has spoken to you and you've been encouraged as well. Take your Bible if you will and turn with me to Acts chapter 13. Acts chapter 13. And I'm going to do something a little different than I normally do tonight. I usually read a scripture, pray and preach. But tonight I'm going to pray and read some select scripture in Acts chapter 13 and then preach. So let's pray and ask God to help us in this time together. Lord I am so thankful for being here at Fellowship Baptist Church. I'm thankful for the fellowship that I've been ever able to have with Pastor and his family and with those that I have been able to see. Lord I am so grateful for the faithfulness of your people as they tune in to live stream. I know it's not the easiest thing to do and I am just grateful that they love you, love your word and care about pleasing you with their time but also learning something that can help them please you with their lives. So Lord we ask you to continue to work and we pray tonight that your Holy Spirit would just take your word and apply it to our hearts in the ways that we need it applied and may we be people who are ready to hear and Lord ready to submit to what you teach us. I pray for you to speak to us so that we can be helped in our service to you. I ask it in Jesus name. Amen. I want to read four verses out of chapter 13. I want to begin with verse 22. Note it. And when he had removed him, he raised up unto them David to be their king. To whom also he gave testimony and said, I have found David the son of Jesse, a man after mine own heart, which shall fulfill all my will. Normally when I read that verse I am arrested, I stop and contemplate that phrase a man after mine own heart. God doesn't say that about anybody else in the word of God, but he says it about David. And I think it's significant and I won't hazard to this sermon say what I think that means because I don't want to take the time, but what an honor for God to look at your life and say that's a man who has my heart. He's after mine own heart. But tonight the emphasis that I see in that verse is not on that phrase after mine own heart. My emphasis is on the last words of that verse, which shall fulfill all my will. I don't know that there would be any higher accolade that I would try and achieve than from the day I got saved back in 1975 until the day that God decides that he is going to take me home, that God could look at the life of Mike Edwards and say he fulfilled everything I gave him to do. David's course was not an easy course and it was an unusual life, but David was careful even though he was a flawed man. And we're all flawed people. But the marvelous thing is that a man, even though he is flawed and even though he falls with God's grace and help, he can get back up and complete the course that God has for him. I notice a second man. Look at verse 25. And as John, notice this word, fulfilled his course. He said, Whom think ye that I am? I am not he. But behold, there cometh one after me whose shoes of his feet I am not worthy to lose. The second time, the second man, God says about John the Baptist, he fulfilled his course. Boy, I would suggest to you tonight that the course of John's life was certainly no easy course. He was a hard man, a man who lived in the wilderness much of his life, a man who did not have the dainties, the luxuries that others had in life, not in dress, not in food, not in housing. He was a rough man. And I'd also remind us that the end of John's life was not a sweet time gathered around his family, but John lost his head at the request of a pagan and wicked woman, and a wicked king gave her her desire, and he was beheaded for his testimony for Jesus Christ and for righteousness. And yet God looks at that man and says, he fulfilled his course. There's a third man that's mentioned in this passage. Look at verse 29. And when they had, here it is again, fulfilled all that was written of him, they took him down from the tree and him in a sepulcher, but God raised him from the dead. Well, we know who we're talking about, though his name is not used in verses 29 and 30. We're talking about the Lord Jesus Christ. And though the Bible says here that they fulfilled all that was written of him, understand this, Jesus did not have his life taken, he laid down his life for all of us. And any time he would have wanted to come off the cross or stop the process, he could have but called to his Father or called 10,000 angels, and legions of angels would have come to his aid. No, he fulfilled the hardest course that any man has fulfilled in this life. He died for those who did not love him. He died for those who were sinners when he never one time in his 33 years sinned. Oh, Jesus fulfilled the plan of redemption that had been set from before the foundation of the world, and I stand here tonight a saved man, not because of anything in my life that I have done or accomplished, but simply by the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ. And that is true of you if you're saved tonight. And I thank God that Jesus fulfilled all that was written of him. Now listen, we're not talking about David tonight because he was a king. We're not talking about John Baptist tonight because he was the great and last of the Old Testament prophets, and was the forerunner for Jesus Christ. We're not talking about Jesus tonight because he was prophet and priest and king. I want you to understand what that word fulfilled intimates in each of their lives. They fulfilled what someone else gave them to do. You know what we call that? They were servants. They were servants. Look at verse 36. For David, after he had served his own generation by the will of God, fell on sleep, was laid unto his fathers, and saw corruption. But he whom God raised again saw no corruption. I don't think I do damage to the scripture if I say to you, what is said of David is true also of John. What is said of David is true also of Jesus, that they served their own generation, not by their own will, not in their own way, but by the will of God Almighty. They were servants of God. I don't think you'll ever read the name of Mike Edwards in Who's Who. I don't even know if they have Who's Who anymore. I don't think that you'll ever read my biography unless I write it for myself. Don't intend to do that. I don't think I'll ever be a king. I know I will never be a king. I will never be a great prophet. I struggle to be a coherent preacher. I don't think, I know I will never attain to the level of Jesus Christ, prophet, priest, and king. But I'll tell you what I can do. I can be a servant. were manned not by the elite of society not by the educated of society not by the Greek citizen not by the Roman citizen they were manned by the lowest of slaves they were rode by those who had but it shall not be so among you but whosoever will be great among you let him be your minister and whosoever will be chief among you let him be your servant even as the Son of Man came not to be starting our churches have been 40 years ago we had moved out of the high school and we had purchased a very ramshackle the old building on a couple of acres three acres and and we were trying to make it presentable and my wife and I were in there painting and we had just hired an assistant part time and he was in there painting with us and the phone rang and I had to go down and take a phone call legitimate I had to deal with something about 20 minutes later I'm walking back down the hall towards the nursery that we were painting and and I hear this conversation I hear this young assistant say to my wife I didn't go to Bible college for years to paint walls he did not have an appreciation of who he was talking to I heard her say back to him no we got saved to do this who do we think we are can I remind us tonight that we are under rollers we are servants we are saved to serve listen David understood that being the king brought not only the privilege of the office but the responsibility of service I think of how many years that man even though he had been anointed to be king and God had taken his hand off of Saul he humbled himself and served Saul you talk about tough to swallow serving a guy whom you know you're replacing and he did it right and sweetly I think of David understanding the need to serve the less fortunate men that couldn't give back to him as he brought lame Mephibosheth the son of Jonathan to his palace and set him at his table and gave him a perpetual place at his table he understood the need to serve as God as he prepared materials for the temple that God had told him no you can't build it I don't know about you but boy I don't know about you but I don't know about you but I don't know about you I'd have probably been upset about that and say, well, okay, if I can't build it, if I can't get the glory from it, then let Solomon figure it out. But you know what David did? Because he had a servant's heart and he knew he was an under rower, David said, let me gather the materials, let me get the plans drawn, let me get it figured out and let me take it all to my son Solomon and give it to him to be done. And it's amazing to me today, even though David did all of that, it is called Solomon's Temple. And David has no issue with that. Because David had a servant's heart. It wasn't all about him. John the Baptist certainly understood servanthood. As that powerful, dynamic man stood there and said, he must increase, I must decrease. What a powerful thought. To know that you possess real ability, to know that you have a great following, to know that your name is well known and to willingly say, I will be submissive to this one and to this one whom I have prepared the way, I will gladly allow him to surpass me. What a man. Look to Jesus and you know what you'll find? You'll find him the king of glory with a towel and a basin washing the feet of his disciples. He's all, we call them disciples, but can we just make a little bit of understanding of who they are? He's washing the feet of a man who will sell him for 30, or has sold him for 30 pieces of silver. He's washing the feet of a man who will deny him three times when it comes down to it. He's washing the feet of all of those who when he is arrested will forsake him and run. We sometimes get all upset with Thomas or Peter or Judas. We do realize every one of them forsook him. I don't know about you, but that night in the upper room, I might have looked up in Peter's eyes and says, you know, I'm not gonna wash the dirty feet of a denier. I feel pretty sure I'd have struggled with the feet of Judas. And I'll tell you, I'd have come to John and I'd have looked at John and said, man, you laid your head on my chest. You're known as the disciple of love and you're gonna run. And yet he dutifully washed their feet, gave what they needed. My favorite parable, or one of them, is that of the Good Samaritan in Luke 10. And I won't belabor this, but there were three men, there was a Jew who had been on business or been to temple or whatever, but he had been set upon by robbers and he had been left in the ditch, ready to die, bleeding, not gonna make it. And the Bible tells us that three men came down that road. The first man that came down that road was a priest. If anybody should know the heart of compassion of God, certainly it would be a priest who had a course of duty in the temple. He would understand the heart of God. But the Bible says before he even came to the man, he crossed to the other side of the road and walked on by. Bible says the next man down the road was a Levite. Hey, a man who studied the word, a man who led worship, a man who knew who God was. And the Bible says that when he saw the man, he came over and looked upon him. I see him in my mind, kneeling and looking in that beaten, dying man saying, where's the preacher? You see, it's always the preacher's job to go down into the ditch and to serve in that humble way. But the real point of the parable is, it's every believer's job. Because every believer is called to serve. That Samaritan comes down the road. If anybody should have a reason not to go down in that ditch it is the Samaritan. But the Bible teaches us that he got down off of his donkey, went down into that ditch using his own resources, bound up the wounds of that man, carried that man, put him on his donkey, took him to the inn, paid for his stay, and at the end of it, God just asks us a simple question, who is his neighbor? Oh, we want to be seen as believers and loving people and serious in our walk for the Lord. And we don't have a moment for a lost, bleeding generation. The Bible college that I went to outside the administration building had this on a stone monument, this saying, enter to learn, go forth to serve. And I've walked past that a thousand times and I've thought to myself, that's kind of a nice saying, I'm not quite sure what it is, but enter to learn, go forth to serve. And I'll tell you, the longer I've pastored, I've understood it. You know what we are these days? We enter to learn, we enter to learn, we enter to learn. Who put the coffee on? Who's got the donuts? Because we're having Bible study. We enter to learn, we enter to learn. We've got a meeting, oh, what a speaker. We've got to, we enter to learn, we enter to learn, we enter to learn. And so rarely go forth to serve. And sometimes we just have to ask ourselves, is this the Christianity that Jesus intended? That we know all about him, and yet never get off of our donkey and get down in the ditch with a bleeding and lost generation and try to help them. Not only did they serve, they served by the will of God. Notice that with me. I'll say this to you, the world has never been greatly impressed with anyone doing the will of God. If you're waiting for somebody to applaud you and your neighbor, oh, look at that, they're going to church on Tuesday night. Aren't they awesome? They look at you and think, what's wrong with them? If they knew that you tithed and gave to missions, they'd say, what in the world? I'm just saying to you that the world has never been impressed with anybody doing the will of God. But can I suggest to you that the wisdom of man is foolishness in the eyes of God? And you and I ought to find the will of God and do it regardless of what any man thinks. Michael thought it was foolish that David danced before the ark when the ark was brought into Jerusalem, but it was a day of rejoicing in the will of God. Judas thought it was absolutely silly and wasteful for Jesus to be anointed with that expensive oil, but it was the will of God. Peter rebuked the Lord for saying he was going to suffer and die upon the cross, but it was the will of God. And I say to us tonight, let the world have its opinions. Let formal Christendom have its opinions. Our lives and our ministries are not based on the approval of the world. They are based on the commandments and the ultimate approval of God as God set forth how he wants us to live. The world may scoff at preaching, but preaching is still the will of God. The Bible howls at the thought of holy living. Why don't you do what all the rest of us do? Well, because God's not pleased with some of those things. Obey God. World hates confrontational soul winning, telling a man that he's a sinner, telling a woman that she needs to know Jesus Christ. The world hates that and in many places tries to outlaw that, but it is the will of God. The world may sneer at parents who accept the God given responsibility of training our own children, but it is the will of God. And you and I have to make a fundamental decision that I'm going to serve and I'm going to serve not in a modern way, not in a way that's acceptable to the world, but in a way that is acceptable and pleasing to the Lord. Now mark this. When I come into this room and I'm on live stream preaching at Fellowship Baptist Church, I love the stuff I'm saying. Hey, preaching is what God wants. Soul winning is what we need to do. Holy living is what we need to pursue. And you know why I love to do it? I love to get kind of wild with it and I love preaching like that. You know why? Because most everybody agrees with me in here. You know where I'm not near as excited about it? Out there, where absolutely nobody. wants to hear what I have to say. Can I remind you of something? Jesus came unto his own and his own received him not and therefore Jesus decided not to go to the cross, not to humble himself and decided to go back to heaven and let mankind find him. That's not true is it? He was forsaken, he was denied, he was rejected and he marched right on to the cross because, ready for this? He was an underroar. Well I'm not going to tell somebody about Jesus because they they might think less of me. Hey, how can you think less of an underroar? The question we need to ask ourselves is, who do we think we are? Are we too good to follow in the steps of our Savior? Are we too good when he emptied himself and made of himself no reputation and took upon himself the form of a servant and was obedient unto death, even the death of the cross? Who do we think we are? Too good, too busy. Friends, we're underroars and our calling in life is to, as our Master did not come to be ministered to, but instead came to minister and give his life a ransom for many. Let me speak finally, just a moment on this thought. Our generation, who did you ever think you would live in a world like we live in? Can I be honest with you? I hope you'll let me and not think less of me. Sometimes in my life I just come to the place where I would like to take any money that I have and go up in the deepest holler of West Virginia and buy a couple hundred acres and at the opening of the holler just put a wall. I would take my wife and my kids, I'd definitely take my dog, I would take my grandchildren, my children, both of my friends, I've only got two, and I would close that wall off and I would say, leave us alone. But you see, that life would indicate that I am self-interested, self-serving, self-focused. That would mean I was the guy who didn't want to be bothered with the bleeding man in the ditch and I was the guy who looked at him and thought somebody should help him, but it can't be me, I can't do that. No, we are called to engage with this generation. Can I be honest with you? The behavior of this generation is repugnant to me. I don't know all the letters, but LGBTQ, that's a lifestyle that I don't believe is consistent with the Word of God. I don't understand all the drug use, I don't understand all the piercings, I don't understand all the tats, I don't understand, honestly, I don't understand how a legislature of men and women can vote on a bill that allows a baby to be born and then slain in the delivery room, and then when you sign the bill that allows that, an entire legislature stands and applauds. That's repulsive. But they're ours. They're our generation. And somewhere, somehow, you and I have to remember that God placed us here at this time and he knew all of those things, and yet he says to us, serve by the will of God your generation. Sometimes it's so big that I don't see how it can possibly be done, and it's so awful that I don't feel like I want to even be part of it. I don't know how you win this world, I don't know how you win this city, I don't know how you win this community, but I do know this. I know how to see a guy lying in a ditch and trying to help him. I won't belabor this, but I guarantee you something. If I could draw a five-mile circle around this church tonight, I could find some certain things. I guarantee you I could find a man who was injured, perhaps, at work. I'm making this up. And for a time, the company was helping him, and they were writing prescriptions for painkillers, and boy, he just really was hurting. And then the doctor said, well, I can't write those prescriptions anymore, and the pain was still there. And he started looking for those pills somewhere else. And you say, wow, he's really in bad shape, and his family is suffering because of it. Boy, that's weak. I can't stand that kind of person. I don't want to be around that kind of person. Hey, I guarantee you that man, he can't go to his work, his boss, and say, man, I'm hooked. I'm stuck. What do I do? He'll be fired. But I do know a group of people who know the answer for that man. It's not a simple answer, but the answer is Jesus Christ. That guy you work with, that you know he's having trouble in his home, that kid that you go to school with, and you know they're going down the wrong path. I'm saying to us, look, I can't win a city. I can't win a nation. I can't win a world. But I can be a servant. I can be a friend to a man or woman that God leads me by, who is lying in a ditch, bleeding and dying. But we've become so self-interested, so self-focused, that we, like the priest, run by because we've got to get to our job in the commute, you know, and because Saturday's our only day, you know, and because, oh well, you know, I'm not good at that, you know. Hey, can I remind you that we are under rowers? Can I remind you that but by the grace of God, that's us? As a matter of fact, some of us who are saved today, that was us. You know what I'm asking God to do tonight? To remind us of who we are. To remind us that we are servants. And yes, we live in a horrendously ugly generation. They save whales and kill babies. I get it. They have more sympathy for a puppy than for a human being. But they are our generation. And God has placed us here for such a time as this. And it is time that we stop building empires in our churches and stop looking for what pleases me and what I like and why isn't someone serving me. Why, you forgot me, me, me, me, an under rower. Nobody needs to coddle you. We're just under rowers. You there at livestream and you in this room, here's what I'm asking God to do. In all the stages of our life and all the places of our life, you and I have someone that we come in contact with that is a bleeding, dying person in a ditch. We rush past them or we hope someone will help them. We hope someone will deal with them. I'm asking God to lay a name on your heart. Not a city, not a nation, a name. Might be someone that you already know and God has spoken to your heart. Might be somebody you work with. It might be the neighbor next door and you know that lady is so unhappy, and you know that she's in distress, and you know it. She doesn't know where to turn, but you know the answer. You know Jesus Christ is the answer. But until we come to the place in our lives where we are willing to fulfill what God has given us to do amongst this generation in which he's placed us, we'll be the priest hurrying by. We'll be the Levite wishing somebody would do something. We need to get down off our donkeys and get down in the ditch and be the friend to that person, the servant to that person with the ideal and hope of leading them to Jesus Christ. Would you pray with me? Father, I pray that every head is bowed in this room, every head is bowed in these homes, and Holy Spirit, I ask you to do something just now. Would you please, in the quietness of this moment, would you lay a name on the heart of every believer that is listening? Maybe a neighbor or a workmate, it may be someone they go to school with, maybe someone that comes to church, maybe someone they know from business, but God, would you speak to their heart and lay that name on their heart? And in the next days and weeks to come, I pray that these folks that you've laid the name on their heart will be intentional with you, asking you, God, to help them. Well, I can't deliver the gospel. You can be a friend and a help. You can show love to a person that desperately needs it. You can get them to Jesus. And I pray that they would purpose in their hearts, Lord, if you'll lay someone on my heart, I will minister to that person with the goal of leading them to Jesus Christ. I know it's hard, but God, we are servants. Lord, I pray for those who are under the sound of my voice that you didn't lay a name on their heart. I ask them to do this. Will you, in this invitation, ask God to lay someone on your heart? Lord, help us. We curse the darkness, we're repulsed by the sin of the world that surrounds us, and yet we so focus on ourselves that we never reach a handout. We're never even convicted to tell somebody Jesus loves them. We're never even moved to give them a track. Lord, break that selfishness in our hearts tonight. Lay someone on our heart, and may we purpose to lead that one to Jesus by serving, serving them. Help us, I pray, in Jesus' name. Amen.
